text:
As camera technology continues to grow
from HD to 8k resolutions and beyond,

the challenge of distributing these massive
amounts of media grow greater.
Enter RED Digital Cinema and MediaMonks,

two companies who collaborated
to bring a Post Malone concert

to VR headsets in stunning clarity
with almost no latency.

Join us as we go all in on how these
early adopters are building

a new cloud-centric distribution model
from the ground up.

Uday, thanks for taking the time to explain
to us a little bit about the involvement

of RED Connect
and the Post Malone concert.

Could you tell us a little bit more about
that workflow and how RED integrated?
Sure, so our customer MediaMonks

came to us looking for a solution
for a live AR and XR.

And that solution depends on 
many parts of the RED ecosystem.

It starts with an 8K sensor
and on top of that 8k sensor
we put a special dual fisheye lens

so you can capture a left eye view
and a right eye view both in 4K.

The next challenge is getting that
live view processed for AR/VR viewing.

So we actually offload the footage
live to a GPU where we generate a de-warped

image that's re-compressed and uploaded
to the Cloud for distribution.

But tell me a little bit about
how is this different than, say,
a traditional workflow for this?

So a few years ago when we were doing
similar workflows, it was all file

based and you would actually record
a left camera and a right camera

pull footage from both cameras
and then offline processing

maybe in the data center
or maybe on a local GPUs.
But it wasn't a live workflow.

It wasn't the type of thing that you can
enjoy as the event is happening.

It was more something that you'd see
if you wanted to relive the event in AR/XR
after the fact.

By going to a connected workflow
and interfacing directly to the GPU,

we took what used to be an after the event
and made it a live streaming.

Wow. So that latency
then becomes really impactful
to be able to do that as a live stream.

Tell me, how do you actually get
the network bandwidth to make that happen?

So there are a few key parts of technology
that let us actually

use just a simple 10 gigabit ethernet
to move read code raw

from the camera
to the GPU for full processing.

The GPU does the de-warping on the stream
as it's coming in live in real time

and then re-compresses it
so that our partner can uplink

that footage to the Cloud
and then distribute it.

Really great. So tell me a little bit about as you're
taking that imagery in the GPU,

what are you actually doing in that
de-warping process?

It's a pretty straight forward
de-warping of a fisheye lens to an eco-rectangular view

to make it suitable for both the left eye
and a right eye view of the headset.

And by doing this in
real time and live,

you can actually show a
separate left view

and right view to a
headset viewer

so that they feel immersed
in the experience.

Is there a way that I could experience
that headset?
I believe you can.
I believe we have some hardware here that you can try out.
Fantastic.
This is really cool.

I can totally, like,
see different experiences all around me.

And then there's actually
somebody over there.

I feel like I'm
watching the concert with someone.
So tell me as I'm doing this,

how many different camera shots
would this have taken?
So the strange thing is

this entire immersive view is taken
from a single camera position.
Really?
That's a...
It's phenomenal.

The high resolution sensor lets you see
the fine detail wherever you're looking.
That is what's.

That is what's really phenomenal is it
actually feels like it's really here.

And I know that I'm probably looking
all over the place, but it is really neat
that it feels like it's everywhere.

Uploading these large files to the Cloud
is a huge feat,
but it’s only half the story.

Now, it’s time for MediaMonks to step
in to edit, package,
and deliver the final project in 8k quality.

The Post Malone Twelve Carat Toothache in VR was a project
that was shot with multiple RED Raptor XLs

that were custom modified
specifically for the production of VR.

The original plan was we were going to ship out
drives to our editors in Europe,

our editor, myself, actually here
I was going to edit in this room
here in Raleigh, North Carolina.

We were going to back up
to like three or four raids.

We were going to be golden we would have
been ready to go.

At the time I had seen
this product called Snowcone
an AWS Snowcone advertised.

So what’s great about working with
a Snowball or a Snowcone is

once your stuff is up on S3, it's
backed up across multiple local zones.

It goes into glacial or even deep glacial
like we used on this particular project

as well, and it counts as multiple viable,
redundant backups.
A drive would be left in Los Angeles,

another drive would be shipped
back to me in North Carolina,

and the third backup
would head on out to Amsterdam.
Got home the next day,

a big hard plastic case
shows up on my doorstep.

I pick it up and it starts jingling
like there's a metal puzzle inside.
Another fun factor here is that weekend

and that coming week
was the week of my wedding anniversary.

So I was getting ready to tell my wife
that we were going to spend

our wedding week in a romantic edit
suite with no windows in Amsterdam.
And wasn't that going to be great?
But one of the team members suggested,
hey it's up on S3,

why don't we just work with it on S3?
And why don't we engage with that?

Now, look, if the editor needs to work
with you on cuts in person

so you have that ability to vibe back and
forth, why doesn't he just come to you?

And if you need to access raw,
you can just pull it down from the Cloud.
No problem at all.
And we said, you know what, let's try it.
Let's do that.
And so we did.
We started editing at 9 a.m. on Monday.

So two days after leaving set or two
or three days after set

and we delivered to all of our deadlines
on time, the team was able to work around

a global around the clock 24 hour a day
schedule to get our shots done on time.

Where there's a lot of skepticism
in the media and entertainment industry
around new technology.
We're usually not curing cancer.
Actually, we almost always are not.

And the people who actually are
are using the Cloud,

the people who run the global
banking systems, all of that stuff,

medical systems, aviation systems,
all, in fact, run on the Cloud.

So why is it good enough for them
but not good enough for us?
It works and it's functional.

And we were able to deliver in VR at 8K
at 60 frames a second,

a project built almost completely
on the Cloud for post-production
on time without skipping a beat.

The demand for quick-turnarounds with massive file
sizes are not going away anytime soon.

Together, RED and MediaMonks leverage
Cloud-based workflows

and realize cost-saving efficiencies
for large-scale media productions.
As the Cloud changes the economics of productions

continuous innovations drive the
Media & Entertainment industry forward.
